coredata.dc:title: Direct evidence of binuclear structure in a silica-supported copper catalyst
coredata.dc:creator: Nomura, Masaharu
Kazusaka, Akio
Kakuta, Noriyoshi
Ukisu, Yuji
Miyahara, Koshiro
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Structures of two copper catalysts, one with high catalytic activity, prepared from copper(II) acetate monohydrate and the reference prepared from tetraamminecopper(II), were determined by EXAFS and XANES. In the former catalyst, about 65% of the copper takes a binuclear structure highly dispersed on silica, whereas highly dispersed mononuclear species are dominant in the latter.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 122, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 December 1985 DIRECT EVIDENCE OF BINUCLEAR STRUCTURE IN A SILICA-SUPPORTED COPPER CATALYST Masaharu NOMURA Phoron Fucforr. National Ldhorarort- for High Enerçr Phnrics. Oho -machi. Tsukuha-gun, Iharaki 305. Japan Akio KAZUSAKA_ Noriyoshi KAKUTA. Yuji UKISU and Koshiro MIYAHARA Research Instinue for Carah-sis. Hokkaido Uniocrsirn Sapporo 060. Japan Received 27 July 1985: in final form 6 September 1985 Structures or two copper catalysts- one with high catalytic activity- prepared from copper(II) acetate monohydrate and the reference prepared from lelraamminecopper(11)_ were determined by EXAFS and XANES. In the former catalyst. about 65% of the copper takes a binuclear structure highly dispersed on silica- whereas highly dispersed mononuclear species are dominant in the latter- 1. Introduction A silica-supported catalyst prepared from copper(11) acetate monohydrate by means of impregnation is known to be more active than that obtained from tetraamminecopper(II) by means of ion exchange. The oxidation of CO with 120 is a typical example [ 1 ] _ Kakuta et al. [1 ] interpreted that copper species on the silica support takes a binuclear structure similar to copper(II) acetate monohydrate, and that this species is the active site in this reaction. This interpretation is supported by the results of ESR and IR spectroscopic studies [1 ,2] with acetic acid as a probe molecule, but their results give only indirect evidenceWe have carried out EXAFS (extended X-ray absorption fine structure) and XANES (X-ray absorption near edge structure) studies on these catalysts and obtained direct evidence that there exists binuclear species on the support. 2. Experimental The silica-supported catalyst derived from copper(II) acetate (Ac-Cu/Si02) was prepared by impregnation 538 and then dried at 100°C overnight. The reference one (Am-Cu/Si02) was prepared from tetraamminecopper(II) complex by ion exchange and treated similarly [1,2]. Both samples contained about 3 wt% copper. Powdery catalysts were sealed in glass cells of 3 mm thick fitted with Kapton windows. Liquid samples were contained in a cell of 1 _5 mm thickness fitted with Kapton windows. Measurements of EXAFS and XANES were made in the transmission mode at the Cu K absorption edge using the synchrotron radiation source at the Photon Factory [3]. Copper(II) acetate monohydrate, its saturated aqueous solution, Cu foil (6 ,um thick), bisacetylacetonatocopper(II), and copper(II) oxide were selected as reference samples. EXAFS measurements were carried out at least three times for each sample. 3. Resuls and discussion XANES spectra of Ac-CU/Si02, Am-Cu/Si02 , and their reference samples are shown in fig. 1. Small peaks A, which are due to 1 s - 3d transitions, show that the oxidation states of copper are two,-because there is no 3d hole in the ground state of Cu-" or CuO. 0 009-2614/85/$ 0330 © Elsevier Science Publishers B_V_ (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) Volume 122, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 December 1985 8960 8980 9000 9020 9040 8960 8980 9000 9020 9040 El eV El eV Fig. I. XANES spectra of (a) copper(II) acetate monohydrate, (b) aqueous solution of copper(II) acetate, (c) catalyst Ac-Cu/Sí02 prepared from copper(II) acetate by impregnation, (d) tetraamminecopper(II) and (e) catalyst Am-Cu/Si0= prepared from tetraamminecopper(II) by ion exchange- Peaks A-D of copper(II) acetate monohydrate appear at energies identical with those of Ac-CU/Si02. This feature supports that the electronic configuration and symmetry of the copper site are similar in these samples. The XANES spectrum of an aqueous solution of copper(II) acetate is not similar to that of copper(II) acetate monohydrate, but is quite similar to that of copper(II) formate tetrahydrate (not shown in the figure). This similarity suggests that the main species in the solution take mononuclear structure(s). The spectra of tetraamminecopper(II) complex and Am-Cu/SiO-, resemble each other. This resemblance suggests the structural similarity of these species. The pre-edge backgrounds of the EXAFS spectra were fitted with quadratic equations, because there is no physical meaning in expressing it with Victoreen's formula- The Fourier transform of k3X(k) over the range of wave vectors approximately 3.5 `k ` 15 A-1 are shown in fig. 2 without phase-shift correction. Other analyses were performed as reported in ref. [4] . Three prominent peaks appear at 1.58, 2.26 and 2.68 .L in fig- 2a, and are assigned from the Fourier transform using the structure parameters determined by X-ray diffraction [5]. Peak A reflects the Cu-O bonds of the carboxyl groups, peak B the Cu-OHM and Cu...Cu, and peak C the Cu ...C of the carboxyl groups and the Cu...O of the carboxyl groups in the neighboring molecules. The Fourier transform on Ac-Cu/SiO, (fig- 2c) is similar to that on copper(lI) acetate monohydrat:2_ This similarity indicates that a significant amount of copper species on the silica takes a binuclear structureHowever, the third peak in fig. 2c is not so clear as that in fig. 2a, and this decrease in the intensity indicates that there is little inter-molecular ordering in 12 0 12 9 6 3 0 :I ,llñ= lal (b) 2 3 4 5 6 r/Å r=ig- 2_ Fourier transforms of EJtAi-S_ Symbols (a)-(e) correspond to those in fig- 1_ 539 Volume 122, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 December 1985 Table 1 Extracted structural parameters Cu-O(N) Cu _ Cu r (A) rr r (A) 1_95 2_42 1.94 1 _94 2.41 2.02 b) J_95 Cu2(Ct13C00)4• 2Hí0 Cu2(CFI3C00).t • 2H20 aq Ac-Cu/S i0= [Cu(NH3)a l SOa- l12O Am-Cu/SíO2 °) Coordination numbers arc fixedb) Lígands arc nitrogen atoms. 4.Oa) 2_58 1_Oa) 1_0 a) 3_9 4_8 2.57 0_66 1.2 5_0 b) 4.2 Ac-Cu/SiO,_ Therefore the formation of the binuclear unit in Ac-Cu/Sí02 does not mean the crystal growth on the silica- The presence of a binuclear structure on the silica contrasts with the case oFa saturated copper(I1) acetate aqueous solution, which takes mononuclear structures (probable main species an aquo-complex) as shown in fig. 3b. So the binuclear units are formed not in the solution, but on the silica. The results of the non-linear least-squares fits on the bath-transformed peaks in the k-space are given in table 1 _ The interatomic distance between the nearest copper atoms of Ac-CU/Si02 (2.57 A) corresponds wel: to that of copper(II) acetate monohydrate (3.58 A) and the coordination number of copper atoms in the former sample is about 65`70 of that of the latter one- As the coordination numbers of oxygen atoms around the binuclear and mononuclear copper áre four 540 and six, respectively, the average number becomes 4.7. This agrees well with the value determined from the fitting (4.8). Therefore the model that about 65% of copper takes the binuclear structure bridged with acetate groups and the rest takes the mononuclear one is strongly supported. This ratio also agrees well with that determined from ESR spectroscopic studies On the other hand, no direct Cu __.Cu interaction can be seen in fig. 2e; Am-Cu/Si02 exists as a highly dispersed state. A small peak around 2.9 A is derived front Cu ___Cu interaction which is found in Cu0 [6], and this means Am-Cu/Si02 is partly oxidized during drying it in air at 100°C. In conclusion, Am-Cu/Si02 is a highly dispersed mononuclear catalyst- On the other hand, Ac-Cu/Sí02 is a binuclear catalyst with rather high dispersion. Strong metal-metal interaction in Ac-Cu/Sí02 should be the keypoint in interpreting the high catalytic activity of this catalyst. References [ 1 ] N. Japan 55 (1982) 3911_ [5 ] G_11, Drown and R. Chídambarm, Acts Cryst_ H39 (1984) 2393_ [6] S. Åsbrink and LA- Norrby. Other analyses were performed as reported in ref. [4] . Three prominent peaks appear at 1.58, 2.26 and 2.68 .L in fig- 2a, and are assigned from the Fourier transform using the structure parameters determined by X-ray diffraction [5]. Peak A reflects the Cu-O bonds of the carboxyl groups, peak B the Cu-OHM and Cu...Cu, and peak C the Cu ...C of the carboxyl groups and the Cu...O of the carboxyl groups in the neighboring molecules. The Fourier transform on Ac-Cu/SiO, (fig- 2c) is similar to that on copper(lI) acetate monohydrat:2_ This similarity indicates that a significant amount of copper species on the silica takes a binuclear structureHowever, the third peak in fig. 2c is not so clear as that in fig. 2a, and this decrease in the intensity indicates that there is little inter-molecular ordering in 12 0 12 9 6 3 0 :I ,llñ= lal (b) 2 3 4 5 6 r/Å r=ig- 2_ Fourier transforms of EJtAi-S_ Symbols (a)-(e) correspond to those in fig- 1_ 539 Volume 122, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 December 1985 Table 1 Extracted structural parameters Cu-O(N) Cu _ Cu r (A) rr r (A) 1_95 2_42 1.94 1 _94 2.41 2.02 b) J_95 Cu2(Ct13C00)4• 2Hí0 Cu2(CFI3C00).t • 2H20 aq Ac-Cu/S i0= [Cu(NH3)a l SOa- l12O Am-Cu/SíO2 °) Coordination numbers arc fixedb) Lígands arc nitrogen atoms. 4.Oa) 2_58 1_Oa) 1_0 a) 3_9 4_8 2.57 0_66 1.2 5_0 b) 4.2 Ac-Cu/SiO,_ Therefore the formation of the binuclear unit in Ac-Cu/Sí02 does not mean the crystal growth on the silica- The presence of a binuclear structure on the silica contrasts with the case oFa saturated copper(I1) acetate aqueous solution, which takes mononuclear structures (probable main species an aquo-complex) as shown in fig. 3b. So the binuclear units are formed not in the solution, but on the silica. The results of the non-linear least-squares fits on the bath-transformed peaks in the k-space are given in table 1 _ The interatomic distance between the nearest copper atoms of Ac-CU/Si02 (2.57 A) corresponds wel: to that of copper(II) acetate monohydrate (3.58 A) and the coordination number of copper atoms in the former sample is about 65`70 of that of the latter one- As the coordination numbers of oxygen atoms around the binuclear and mononuclear copper áre four 540 and six, respectively, the average number becomes 4.7. This agrees well with the value determined from the fitting (4.8). Therefore the model that about 65% of copper takes the binuclear structure bridged with acetate groups and the rest takes the mononuclear one is strongly supported. This ratio also agrees well with that determined from ESR spectroscopic studies On the other hand, no direct Cu __.Cu interaction can be seen in fig. 2e; Am-Cu/Si02 exists as a highly dispersed state. A small peak around 2.9 A is derived front Cu ___Cu interaction which is found in Cu0 [6], and this means Am-Cu/Si02 is partly oxidized during drying it in air at 100°C. In conclusion, Am-Cu/Si02 is a highly dispersed mononuclear catalyst- On the other hand, Ac-Cu/Sí02 is a binuclear catalyst with rather high dispersion. Strong metal-metal interaction in Ac-Cu/Sí02 should be the keypoint in interpreting the high catalytic activity of this catalyst. References [ 1 ] N. head.ce:title: Direct evidence of binuclear structure in a silica-supported copper catalyst

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-gun, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Research Institute for Catalysis, Hokkaido University, Sapporo 060, Japan

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Structures of two copper catalysts, one with high catalytic activity, prepared from copper(II) acetate monohydrate and the reference prepared from tetraamminecopper(II), were determined by EXAFS and XANES. In the former catalyst, about 65% of the copper takes a binuclear structure highly dispersed on silica, whereas highly dispersed mononuclear species are dominant in the latter.
